reviewText: I got this game last weekend and was really impressed by it.  Being able to create your kart and character is a great idea.  You can be very creative when making your stuff.  For example, i made a cardboard kart with a hamster wheel as my engine.  Then i have a another kart that uses a nuclear reactor for the engine.  Character creation is really cool.  I have seen a lot of creative people making iron man, punisher, mario, luigi, a helghast from killzone, jason voorhees, freddy krueger, star war characters.  My game came with a download of sackboy from little big planet and i have been using him in career mode.For career mode, its pretty challenging trying to win a race.  You usually have to make 3rd place in order to win a race for the first part of the game. I'm in the middle of the game right now, and it just changed to where i have to win first place to advanced.  So be aware of that.  For each race, there is a challenge to knock out an opponent or dont bump the side walls and win first place to unlock stuff. Some of the races are easy and some are hard and have to keep restarting to beat it. If you find yourself getting frustrated, take a break from the game and then retry later on, and you'll beat it.The ingame announcers are hilliarous and they insult each other a lot.  Its funny listening to them.  When you lose a race, they will make a funny rude comment about your driving.The special weapons in the game are cool but can be annoying to.  Especially when your about to win first and then you struck by lightning.  How it works is you pick up a weapon, if you dont useit and pick up another one, you increased the power of that weapon.  If you get a third one, its maxed out and you can do some serious damage with it.  There is also a speed boost, if you get three of those and use it, it will send you warp speed and catch you up to the race or help get in winning position.  It saved me a lot of times.The downside to this game is the load times, especially in multiplayer. I heard rumors that there will be a fix to speed that up but i dont know if thats true or not.Overall, its a really fun game.  The demo version was somewhat ok and it made me hesistant to buy it, but when i bought and played, i'm glad i got it.  Reading game reviews is what helped my decision.

summary: This supercharged sequel is familiar, but "electrifyingly" fun
reviewText: Cole MacGrath, the Electric Man, is back for some more sizzling mayhem which is very reminiscent of his previous adventure. Despite certain rumors about being able to carry over saved data from the first Infamous into this game, Sucker Punch has decided to take a different approach in allowing you to "continue" the story of Cole's previous exploits. The game opens with three choices available for the player: begin a new game from scratch with neutral karma, begin the game with some good karma and experience points, or begin the game with some evil karma and experience points. Afterwards, Cole is shown in Empire City recalling the events from the previous game and then being approached by NSA agent Lucy Kuo, who also knows of the eventual arrival of the Beast that Kessler showed to Cole in a vision before he died. Kuo tells Cole about Dr. Wolfe, who helped develop the Ray Sphere, and she suggests that Dr. Wolfe may be able to help Cole gain the power needed to stop the Beast when it makes its move. As Cole, his old buddy Zeke, and Kuo are about to set sail for New Marais to meet up with Dr. Wolfe, the Beast shows up and starts leveling Empire City. Cole does all he can to stop it, but he simply isn't powerful enough to do so. Instead, he barely makes it back to the boat broken, beaten, and with some of his powers drained away. Empire City itself is even less fortunate and ends up getting destroyed by the Beast.Cole and the others eventually arrive at New Marais, the New Orleans of the Infamous universe. While this city is not under government quarantine, it has been put under lockdown by a group of gun wielding yahoos called the Militia, and they are under the leadership of business mogul Bertrand who is on a ruthless campaign to hunt down all Deviants (or Conduits) which are considered to be sub-human; kind of like how people view Mutants in Marvel comics. Cole then sets out on his mission to increase his power so he'll be able to destroy the Beast, which is slowly but surely creating a path of utter destruction along the eastern seaboard as it makes its way towards New Marais to catch up with Cole. With regards to how this game is structured with comic book themed cutscenes, movement and combat controls, the layout of the city, accessing of missions, random encounters, and taking territory back from enemy forces, this game is almost an exact clone of the first one. If any of you have played the Jak and Daxter series, it's a lot like the relationship between Jak II and Jak 3: two VERY similar games with a few tweaks here and there. In order to become more powerful, Cole will have to undertake many missions involving taking out enemies, escorting or accompanying allies through enemy territory, locating important items, and once again restoring power to certain sections of the city (but no running through smelly sewers this time). Of course, Cole will have the choice to complete his missions as a force for good or as a harbinger of destruction.This is one aspect of Infamous 2 that builds up on and surpasses what was done in the first game; while the karmic choices are once again very cut and dry, the way in which Cole acts upon them and the repercussions afterwards are quite varied. Like in the first game, Cole will have to avoid harming or killing citizens and cops if he wants to be good, while his evil persona can do as he pleases. He'll get more numerous opportunities with random encounters to gain large amounts of good or evil karma points: good guys can stop muggings, disarm bombs powered by Blast Shards (which can be acquired afterwards), and heal groups of injured people; bad guys can steal Blast Shards from certain wandering citizens, attack groups of police officers, take out protesters who support Bertrand and verbally bash Cole, or simply kill the people who are injured and being mugged, and even blow up the Blast Shard bombs. There are of course the good and evil side missions like in the first game that offer more karma points. Good missions will have Cole doing things like helping cops and rebels against bad guys and monsters, while evil missions will have Cole destroying parts of the city, letting people get attacked for a while by monsters, and hunting down pro-Militia people.Some of the main missions of the first game offered a few karmic choices which were very plain in their delivery (kill this guy or let him live, blow up innocent people or receive some damage instead, choose the good poster or the bad poster), but some of the main missions in this game are much more dynamic and offer very different karmic routes. Kuo, who eventually acquires ice powers, represents Cole's good karmic alignment, while the more wild (and somewhat annoying) Conduit named Nix, with powers of smog and fire, represents Cole's evil karmic alignment. Zeke kind of goes both ways (no pun intended), but mostly favors the good choices like Kuo. With Kuo and Nix acting as Cole's shoulder angel and devil, Cole will have to side with one or the other during some of these missions. For example, in order to gain the support of a rebel faction, Cole can side with Kuo and deliver medical supplies to the rebels in order to gain their trust, or he can side with Nix who will attack the rebels disguised as a Militia goon and Cole will step in and "save the day" to fool the rebels into relying on him. As a result, these main missions that offer you these karmic decisions will play out very differently depending on which choice you make.Sucker Punch promised us a more powerful Cole MacGrath, and for the most part they deliver on that. However, due to certain gameplay elements which could have been done differently, Cole ends up feeling somewhat underpowered for the majority of the game. From the very beginning he still has his lightning bolts, shockwaves, Static Thrusters, and Shock Grenades, but being drained by the Beast made him temporarily lose his Precision (sniper lightning bolt), electric rockets, his electric shield, and his lightning storm. As you would expect, he does regain these powers and their respective upgrades as you go further in the game, but he doesn't regain the electric rockets until just past the game's halfway point, which kind of sucks since they could have come in handy in earlier missions where Cole fights powerful monsters and annoying attack choppers. He also doesn't regain his most powerful attack, the lightning storm (now the Ionic Storm), until the penultimate main mission, which REALLY sucks since by that point in the game you don't have much of an opportunity to use it. Even the first game allowed Cole to use that power at an earlier point. Still, Cole does gain access to a bunch of other upgrades to his powers and other newer ones, and a lot of them depend on whether Cole is good or evil. While the first game had stunts which were mostly just for fun, this one requires you to perform stunts like hitting bad guys with head shots or using a shockwave to blast them off a roof in order to unlock upgrades, as well as completing a set number of side missions.Once the upgrades have been unlocked, you can use your EXP to purchase them and they include firing three lightning bolts in a single blast, throwing a shock grenade that splits into several smaller ones before detonating, and shooting a longer range Precision bolt. Other powers are acquired after Cole absorbs energy from devices called Blast Cores, which include improved Static Thrusters or the Ionic Vortex where Cole fires an electric blast that creates a miniature tornado that decimates large groups of smaller enemies. Good Cole eventually acquires ice based powers that allow him to create an ice shield or have a pillar of ice shoot up from underneath his feet to greatly increase his jumping height, as well as icy versions of his grenades and missiles. He also gains upgrades to his regular electric attacks like rapid fire lightning bolts, a slower but more powerful lightning bolt with greater range, and the ability to do far less damage to civilians should he accidentally shoot one (greatly cutting down on accidental civilian casualties). Evil Cole acquires fire based powers that let him plow into his enemies like a human rocket, and of course fiery versions of his grenades and missiles.His other upgrades include a more damaging shockwave blast, a lightning bolt that fires about five bolts at the same time horizontally, and temporary use of unlimited energy after bioleeching someone. All these attacks, even the lightning bolt, use up Cole's battery cores, except the Ionic attacks which use up Ionic Charges (up to three of these can be stored). Then there is Cole's melee weapon known as the Amp, which kind of looks like a cross between a pogo stick and a tuning fork. He charges it up and uses it as an electric club to bash his enemies around with some impressive looking spinning strikes and homerun slams, so the melee combat is much improved in this game. All these abilities are necessary for Cole to defeat the many challenging enemies he encounters: the gun wielding Militia, Conduits who use a combination of standard weaponry and ice powers, and creatures known as the Corrupted who come in all shapes and sizes... and just as many forms of ugliness. Different groups inhabit different areas of the two large islands that make up New Marais. Unlike Empire City, this city has many different looking and diverse areas, including a red light district, an industrial zone with warehouses and gas tanks, swamplands, trainyards, and the area known as Flood City. Much like the area of New Orleans after Hurricane Katrina, the neighborhood of Flood City is of course flooded and has many half submerged houses and buildings littering its territory... this area is of course more treacherous for Cole to navigate. It also makes the destruction in Empire City look almost tame in comparison.Blast Shards make a return in this game to increase the amount of energy Cole can store. Dead Drops left behind by Dr. Wolfe are also in this game, except this time they're attached to carrier pigeons who fly in circles around the city and Cole can either lethally shoot them down or use a shockwave to stun them (this doesn't affect karma). Since their general direction can't be picked up by Cole's electric radar ping, these Dead Drops are much trickier to find and only show up on Cole's mini-map when he's relatively close to them. Special mention has to go to the game's graphics: they are much better and prettier to look at than they were in the first game, especially with regards to the character and monster designs. Cole himself looks particularly amazing and his different karmic appearances are more diverse. As Cole rises in the halls of goodness he'll wear a clean white shirt, sport more circular arm tattoos, have a nice tan, his Amp will be clean and shiny, and he'll stand straight and tall with his chest out like Superman. But as Cole falls into the depths of naughtiness he'll wear a dirty and tattered red shirt, sport more sharp and pointy looking tattoos, have a pale complexion and stubble on his chin, his Amp will be rusted and dirty, and his posture will resemble that of Gollum trying to stand on two feet... and let's not forget the red lightning. Motion capture also gives the game a more cinematic look during in-game cutscenes, and even during gameplay Cole runs more realistically and no longer looks like a sprinting robot. As for the game's User Generated Content (UGC), it is well implemented and works nicely, making it possible for players to create some very fun and varied missions of their own that can be played at any time during free roam like regular main and side missions, as well as shared with other players online. However, it does require a lot of time, patience, and some technical know-how in order to really make a mission of substance, and not everyone will be willing to pull off the many detailed and in-depth implementations required for the program to work (including me, apparently).The main game is unfortunately not without a few technical problems that overshadow the less numerous ones in the first game. Defeated enemies and civilians will ocassionally float in midair for no reason, Cole clips through certain surfaces more frequently, and certain attacks by enemies that hurt civilians will count as negative karma towards Cole, which is irritating for good guys. The most glaring technical flaw is the game's camera, specifically when Cole uses melee attacks. It zooms in rather closely on Cole during his more powerful slow motion attacks, so while it certainly looks cool and flashy, it disorients the player and makes them lose sight of other enemies who can attack from offscreen. This is more troubling in confined spaces where the camera could go inside a nearby wall while Cole swings his Amp around. The camera spazzes out even worse when Cole is hit directly by a powerful attack like a missile or a glob of acid spit from a monster; when this happens, the camera zooms in REALLY close to Cole and is again accompanied by a slow motion effect, making it extra infuriating to be slammed by these enemies only to lose sight of Cole amidst a panorama of surrounding explosions or globs of acid.  With less access to Cole's more powerful abilities and the larger number of technical issues with this game, it rather sadly gets an overall score of 4 stars from me, and I really wanted to give this game an overall score of 5 stars. However, with its larger number of other fun powers, challenging enemies, and very different missions depending on your karmic alignment, this game ends up being more fun and much less repetitive than its predecessor, so that's 5 stars for its fun factor. Finally, unlike the final battle and ending in the first game, the good and evil final battles and endings for Infamous 2 could not be more different from each other. Regardless, both endings will leave gamers with their mouths agape for different reasons. Bottom line: if you liked the first Infamous, then Infamous 2 is certainly a worthy successor that is well worth your attention.*UPDATE*This next part will be dedicated to the stand-alone DLC called Festival of Blood. Much like how Red Dead Redemption added zombies to its world with its DLC Undead Nightmare, Festival of Blood adds vampires to the Infamous mythos. The game opens presumably at some point in the middle of Cole's adventure in Infamous 2. However, it's Cole's old buddy Zeke who first appears on the screen sitting at a bar drinking beer and reading a comic book. When an attractive woman enters Zeke's radar, he tries to woo her by telling her a (likely fictitious) story about an adventure that he and Cole undertook sometime after they arrived in New Marais on a popular holiday known as Pyre Night (kind of like a mix between Mardi Gras and Halloween). Zeke's tale begins with some citizens trapped inside the city's church as its interior begins to cave in. Cole goes in to rescue them, but then ends up getting captured by vampires. They take him to their practically dead looking leader Bloody Mary and after reviving her with some of Cole's blood, Bloody Mary bites Cole, beginning the process of turning him into a vampire. Now, unless Cole and Zeke can find a way to kill Bloody Mary before sunrise, Cole will be under her control as her most powerful vampire servant. The gameplay in Festival of Blood is not all that different from that of the main game, but it adds a few new elements that keep the game from getting stale. While only the first island of New Marais is accessible in this game, the look of it has changed somewhat. Gaudy decorations such as large, horror themed balloons, fireworks stations, and rock band stages are set up everywhere to set the mood for the big fiesta of Pyre Night. Even the citizens are all running around wearing silly masks, glowsticks, and other party-themed paraphernalia. Not only that, but Cole will be able to visit a previously unexplored area. He can now go into a long (and kind of creepy) underground tunnel that runs underneath the island. Cole's running and climbing skills are still intact and he can still zap enemies with his classic electric attacks (due to his vampiric transformation, he uses the evil red lightning in this game). He starts with the standard lightning bolts, then gains the shockwave, shock grenades, electric rockets, etc. that he used in the main game as he defeats a required number of enemies.Cole's new melee weapon in this game is a metal stake which actually functions much like the Amp from the main game. While Cole can incapacitate his vampire enemies with his electric attacks, the only way to permanently kill them is by having Cole stake them while they're down. The vampire enemies he faces range from the newborn breeds that simply pile onto Cole in great numbers, the footsoldiers who use crossbow guns, bladed boomerangs, and submachine guns, and the more powerful Firstborn vampires which are basically giant bats who can quickly tear Cole apart if he's not careful. Cole also has a couple of new vampiric abilities to help him complete his mission. For the first time ever, Cole has access to full on flight by turning himself into a swarm of bats, letting him fly high and far at great speeds. He also gains Vampire Vision, which lets him spot vampires disguised as humans and locate hidden vampire glyph messages. These glyphs are supernatural versions of the main game's Dead Drops that reveal interesting background information on Bloody Mary's past exploits. Both of Cole's new vampiric abilities drain his blood meter, which replaces the karma meter (no good or evil karma moments in this game). Cole cannot use his new abilities if the blood meter is drained, so he must drink the blood of citizens in order to fill it up again. Finding Canopic Jars hidden throughout the city extends Cole's blood meter, much like how the Blast Shards in the main game extend his energy meter. To sum up, Festival of Blood is really an enjoyable new take on the Infamous franchise. It doesn't do anything revolutionary, but it does add enough new gameplay elements and abilities to make it worth playing. Plus, the story is pretty interesting too. The only disappointing thing about this game is that it's short..... very short. I beat the main story, collected almost half of the Canopic Jars, and found all 10 glyphs in about three and a half hours. Still, for $10 on the PSN, Festival of Blood is a fun game for fans of Infamous to sink their teeth into...... I had to put ONE vampire joke in here somewhere.

description: The third game in theFalloutseries,Fallout 3is a singleplayer action role-playing game (RPG) set in a post-apocalyptic Washington DC. Combining the horrific insanity of the Cold War era theory of mutually assured destruction gone terribly wrong, with the kitschy naivety of American 1950s nuclear propaganda,Fallout 3will satisfy both players familiar with the popular first two games in its series as well as those coming to the franchise for the first time.The Cold War goes Next-GenWelcome to the nation's capital.View larger.The Brotherhood of Steel is a powerful ally.View larger.Customize characters with your Pip-Boy.View larger.The Story: Vault 101 ? Jewel of the WastesFor 200 years, Vault 101 , a fallout shelter, has faithfully served the surviving residents of Washington DC and its environs, now known as the Capital Wasteland. Though the global atomic war of 2077 left the US all but destroyed, the residents of Vault 101 enjoy a life free from the constant stress of the outside world. Giant Insects, Raiders, Slavers, and yes, even Super Mutants are all no match for superior Vault-Tec engineering. Yet one fateful morning, you awake to find that your father has defied the Overseer and left the comfort and security afforded by Vault 101 for reasons unknown. Leaving the only home you've ever known, you emerge from the Vault into the harsh Wasteland sun to search for your father, and the truth.Key Features:Limitless Freedom!? Take in the sights and sounds of the vast Capital Wasteland! See the great monuments of the United States lying in post-apocalyptic ruin! You make the choices that define you and change the world. Just keep an eye on your Rad Meter!Experience S.P.E.C.I.A.L.!? Vault-Tec engineers bring you the latest in human ability simulation ? the SPECIAL Character System! Utilizing new breakthroughs in points-based ability representation, SPECIAL affords unlimited customization of your character. Also included are dozens of unique skills and perks to choose from, each with a dazzling variety of effects!Fantastic New Views!? The wizards at Vault-Tec have done it again! No longer constrained to just one view, experience the world from 1st or 3rd person perspective. Customize your view with the touch of a button!The Power of Choice!? Feeling like a dastardly villain today, or a Good Samaritan? Pick a side or walk the line, as every situation can be dealt with in many different ways. Talk out your problems in a civilized fashion, or just flash your Plasma Rifle.Blast 'Em Away With V.A.T.S.!?Even the odds in combat with the Vault-Tec Assisted Targeting System for your Pip-Boy Model 3000! V.A.T.S. allows you to pause time in combat, target specific body parts on your target, queue up attacks, and let Vault-Tec take out your aggression for you. Rain death and destruction in an all-new cinematic presentation featuring gory dismemberments and spectacular explosions.Mind-Blowing Artificial Intelligence!? At Vault-Tec, we realize that the key to reviving civilization after a global nuclear war is people. Our best minds pooled their efforts to produce an advanced version of Radiant AI, America's First Choice in Human Interaction Simulation. Facial expressions, gestures, unique dialog, and lifelike behavior are brought together with stunning results by the latest in Vault-Tec technology.Eye-Popping Prettiness!? Witness the harsh realities of nuclear fallout rendered like never before in modern super-deluxe HD graphics. From the barren Wasteland, to the danger-filled offices and metro tunnels of DC, to the hideous rotten flesh of a mutant's face.
summary: Delighted it continued the "fall out tradition" so well!
reviewText: Fall out had humble origins. It started out as a pen and paper post apocalyptic table top role playing game. Eventually it was made into arguably the best 3 pc games ever. Fall out 1, Fall out 2, and fall out tactics are loved and idolized to this day. While they do not have mind blowing graphics there is A LOT to do as you explore the waste land.So did Bethesda get it right with Fall Out 3? Though the game-play is very different (akin to a 1st person shooter or over the shoulder action game)Fall Out 3 is spot on. All your favorite 1940's-1950's songs,deco architecture, sprawling decimated bad lands, and make shift towns held together by a thread make a return. This time you are in Washington DC and it shows through in spades.Making a comparison to Fable 2 I can say the NPCs in Fall out 3 are by far more lovable and interesting. I did not get to know my father James that well before he was forced to leave Vault 101 but he made a lasting impression as a good man. I was angered when Jame's friend Jonas who gave me a B B gun when I was a kid was killed by the fanatic over seer. I felt pity for the over seer's daughter who helped me escape. I even saved Butch's mother from rad roaches though he was a hoodlum that treated me like garbage. Indeed that day despite our rocky past we became "chums".All that is just the introduction/tutorial. It does not explain why your father left the safety of the fall out shelter. It never explains "how" the over seer went crazy or for what reason he ordered his guards to capture you. The answers might be out there...but than again every answer brings with it more questions.The first thing I'll address is that the customization of your character is very detailed. You can be black, Asian, Caucasian, or Hispanic. Everything from your cheek bones to your eyes and chin can be altered. I hear "jokes" about females coming out looking like male cross dressers but my friend Alex blew my mind when he created a sexy red head.Secondly do not be discouraged if you did not like your results with the GOAT entrance exam or the stats you choose from your baby book. Right before you leave the vault you can redo things more to your liking.So what is it like "out there"? It is what you expect fall out to be. You will encounter many people in your travels. You can save them or damn them. You can trade and barter honestly or steal from thy neighbor. Just like the previous game you can be a savior or savage raider and your actions gradually give you a "reputation" making certain people friendly towards you while others will be out gunning for you.One argument was that it was too easy to get bad karma from stealing. I thought this implied when you picked things up you would not get a warning if the property belongs to someone else. Luckily that is not the case. If the text is "green" it is not shop lifting. If the text is "red" it belongs to an owner. Do not fret. Even if you don't pick pockets or loot stores there are plenty of ways to accumulate bottle cap currency and get equipment. Raiders always carry a lot of crap on them + certain creatures can be salvaged for meat you can eat or trade.While it is easy to be evil in the game is is no more difficult to be good. This came as a relief to me because everyone commented how the dastardly road of villainy was much wider. I've not encountered that pit fall yet.To me the best thing about Fall out 3 is it feels like a living breathing world. The people are lively,flawed, and even a simple merchant can have interesting gossip or an inspirational life story. No one truly seems "flat" and "lifeless".It was also nice how even doing the smallest things such as deactivating the atomic bomb and fixing the leaky pipes of Megaton gave me a sense of pride. Bethesda managed to make these little errands "fun". As to how they did it is a mystery.However there are problems with a free roaming real world dynamic. The first of these is that sometimes even when sticking to the straight and narrow and doing a low level quest you may still run into a death claw or super mutant. As you can imagine the end result of that is not pretty.My worst adversaries were when I chose to help a boy find his father. Fire breathing ants attacked the town and came at me from all sides. Trapped and cut off I fled into the subway only to find my eventual demise. Overconfidence can kill you quick in this game. It is fortunate "saving" is automatic and occurs often and that you can also manually save your game from anywhere.For those of you still worried rest assured. Fall Out staples such as the brother hood of steel and the enclave are portrayed in their full heroic and terrifying splendor. There are also ghouls and mini nukes. At first I was skeptical of Bethesda but all my doubts have been officially laid to rest. This is an addicting and fun game! Yes, it has a steep difficulty but if you have played the older games you know that is a fall out trade mark.The only down side I see is there are not quite as many skills and perks. However if you reminisce back on Fall Out 1 and Fall out 2 some of those skills and perks were quite useless anyway. I know some fans maybe disappointed by this which is why I discuss it.Gameplay is an odd fusion. On one hand you can play Fall Out 3 totally as a run and gun affair with 100% live action. However there is also "vats" which allows you to target specific body parts on your enemies and manage how many bullets or strikes per volley you'll execute. Vats is great for precision strategy but you will gradually run out of "action points" forcing you to once again go into quick combat.Personally though this system was hard for me to adapt to at first I was grateful for vats. With it I was able to precisely target my enemies without hurting my allies. In the thick of a chaotic brawl it is truly a life saver.The voice acting, music, and graphics are all superb. I cannot really offer up a critique for the audio or visuals department.Bottom line the only recurring fault is sometimes my game will freeze. I heard it is worse for other people but I have no idea why the problem fluctuates in severity between players.In closing this is as good as gaming gets. Whether you are a long time fan or know nothing about Fall out you owe it to yourself to pick this one up!Pros-Good game mechanics. Vats helps in all precarious situations.-Lovable and quirky NPCs that act like real people- A huge array of quests and ways you can interact with others.-The introduction offers a good story line ensuring your character actually had "family" "friends" and a "life" before entering the post nuclear waste land.-Large variety of enemy types.Cons-Game freezes on occasion.-Steep learning curve near the beginning. Luckily everything becomes second nature after awhile.-Those who miss the "top side view" of the other fall out games may dislike the first person and over the shoulder views.-Not quite so many perks and skills.-A lot of the cheeky and entertaining "promiscuous sexual content" was omitted from Fall Out 3 and the violence in my opinion became even more over the top. Most gamers will not even notice it but I did.

reviewText: I played Demon's Souls like crazy and loved every minute of it. Dark Souls is a lot harder. Once you get the dodge command down it is easier. I really don't like dodging much though. I'd rather stand my ground and fight like a true warrior. Doing so is instant death against the game's many mini-bosses. Dodging at the right time is the key to winning! Dark Souls retains the first game's awesome game play. Fighting, exploring, leveling up and finding new gear are all fun. The graphics and sound are terrific. description: Mario stars in his first RPG in this highly acclaimed role-playing adventure. Excellent 3-D graphics and a rich variety of game play will enthrall Mario and RPG fans alike!InSuper Mario RPG, Mario's beloved Mushroom Kingdom has been thrown into chaos by the appearance of an extraterrestrial villain. This evil and outer space menace, Smithy, brings fear and treachery to the once-pleasant Mushroom Kingdom. Once Smithy crashes into the Star Road, he causes seven stars to be scattered throughout the land.Mario and his friends must recover the Seven Stars and repair the Star Road by making an epic journey to Bowser's castle to confront the dreaded Smithy. Princess Toadstool, Mallow, Geno, and--believe it or not!--Bowser help Mario restore tranquility and happiness to the Mushroom Kingdom.Powerful weapons, sinister spells and other items help Mario complete his harrowing journey. Conflicts take place in animated battle screens. After you choose battle options, the game carries out your fighting commands and spells.There are seven stages and 29 areas to navigate inSuper Mario RPG. Integrating a traditional menu-driven RPG with action and puzzles, this pak offers a medley of playing excitement. The stunning graphics include fully rendered characters and gorgeous landscapes. For fans of Mario and role-playing games alike,Super Mario RPGshouldn't be missed.

description: The Wii Zapper is a gun peripheral that allows the user to insert a Wii Remote and Nunchuk, both sold separately, into either end and play a compatible game. The control stick on the Nunchuk controls player movement (on stages that allow player movement), while aiming the Wii Zapper moves the targeting reticule on the screen. The Zapper comes withLink's Crossbow Training, which helps to familiarize the player with the Zapper in a shooting gallery style game.Link's Crossbow Trainingcontains three game styles: target shooting, defender and ranger.Features:Target Shooting: In target-shooting rounds, players shoot bull's-eyes as they pop up on the screen. In early stages, targets are stationary. As the game difficulty increases in later levels, the targets move. Hitting the center of the bull's-eye nets more points, and hitting targets in succession without missing earns combo multipliers. Link can aim anywhere on the screen.Defender: In defender rounds, players remain stationary but can look and aim in all directions by aiming off screen. Hordes of enemies assault Link, and he must fight them off. These battles have a great deal of variety, from fighting off skeletons in a desert to defending a wagon from boar-riding Bokoblins.Ranger: In ranger rounds, players can move throughout the level using the control stick and aim anywhere they want by aiming the Wii Zapper wherever they want to look. In these missions, Link storms enemy encampments, fights his way through a forest and seeks out his foes while exploring the environments.The Wii Remote and Nunchuk are sold separately
summary: A lot of value for the price.
reviewText: As some users have commented, the ergonomics of the zapper are O.K.  The zapper is reasonably comfortable to hold, and the construction is good.  The remote and nunchuck fit snugly into the casing, and the wires are coiled comfortably into the handle.  However, If you are like me, your hands instinctively expect a trigger to be in the back of the gun.  The trigger is also not spring-loaded, so I've had friends complain that it feels a bit mushy (all the trigger tension comes directly from the "B" button).The Tommy gun-style front trigger takes some getting used to, and is reasonably comfortable after a while.  The buttons on the remote and nunchuck are all fairly accessible, and the analog stick is just where it needs to be for easy thumb access.  I like the zapper a lot for games that require the analog stick for moving the character around (like the Call of Duty series).  If I'm playing a Duck Hunt style game that only requires me to point and fire I'll usually either reach for aPerfect Shotor the shotgun or rifle that comes with one of hunting games (for instance,Cabela's Dangerous Hunts 2011 with Top Shot Elite).As a free game that comes packaged in with the zapper, Link's crossbow trainer is worth at least $5-$10 of the price tag.  The dynamics are pretty simple, but you get multiple carnival games in one.  In target practice mode your character rapidly flies from scene to scene and you have to shoot as many targets as possible.  When you play Defender style you stand in one place (this time you can move the direction you are looking) and you have to kill as many baddies as possible before you're overwhelmed.  The final mode "Ranger" you run around killing baddies hiding in forts and other locations before the time runs out.  (Ranger mode is my personal favorite.)If you are a Wii junkie like myself the gun and game give you plenty of value for a relatively small amount of money.

description: Resident Evil, the game that is often credited with starting the survival-horror genre, is being reinvented for the GameCube. For those unfamiliar with the series, a mysterious corporation has secretly been performing ungodly biotech experiments in the sleepy little town of Raccoon City. When reports of gory attacks come in from nearby areas, two crack military squads are sent to investigate. Players take the role of either sharpshooter Chris Redfield or demolitions expert Jill Valentine to track down the source of the town's problems--specifically, something in a decaying mansion that's mutating animals into grotesque killers and turning humans into bloodthirsty zombies. Supplies and ammunition are scarce, so players have to know when to fight, when to run, and how to keep their wits about them. Players can't afford to waste their shots and expect their characters to survive.The story is being retrofitted with motion-captured animation, next-generation graphics, real-time lighting and shadow effects, new areas, and newly rendered in-game video segments to create an even more cinematic experience. Also, a redesigned combat system lets players attack and defend themselves with a variety of items found in the environment.

reviewText: Let's just say AWESOME!  The look of the Gamecube version of this game is spectacular. There is no way to describe the difference in this version and the original this one is so far beyond anything I had imagined for this game.For me personally I wish they had a way to dumb down the game for someone like me who loves the game but isn't too good at playing it:)  But that's my problem.My complaint is that I had to buy a new system in order to get this game.  I mean I could make the choice not to buy, but then again I couldn't could I because I love Resident Evil.The game is a little hard for someone with my skill level, but for others who are highly skilled it probably won't be.This game shines above it's previous installments and makes you wonder if you actually ever played Resident Evil at all once you play this one.

description: Confront terrors both known and unknown in a explosive battle for survival with F.E.A.R 2: Project Origin for PS3. This action-packed follow-up to Monolith Productions's award-winning supernatural shooter F.E.A.R. begins where the previous game left off. This time, you'll come up against Alma's powers from the perspective of special forces operator Michael Becket. After an enormous explosion has devastated the city of Auburn, you'll quickly discover that what seemed like an ordinary mission to retrieve and interrogate Genevieve Aristide is anything but..caption { font-family: Verdana, Helvetica neue, Arial, serif; font-size: 10px; font-weight: bold; font-style: italic; } ul.indent { list-style: inside disc; text-indent: -15px; } table.callout { font-family: verdana; font-size: 11px; line-height: 1. 3em; } td.vgoverview { height: 125px; background: #9DC4D8 url(http://images.amazon.com/images/G/01/electronics/detail-page/callout-bg.png) repeat-x; border-left: 1px solid #999999; border-right: 1px solid #999999; padding-left: 20px; padding-right: 20px; padding-bottom: 10px; width: 250px; font-family: verdana; font-size: 12px; }Ghoulish supernatural enemies give F.E.A.R. 2: Project Origin a horrific, cinematic feel.View larger.You'll explore and do battle in the dark corners of the ruined city of Auburn.View larger.An enhanced graphics engine offers more dramatic effects.View larger.Improved enemy AI means you'll need better tactics.View larger.Project Origin Run Amok: Alma's BackgroundFans of the first game will be familiar with the suspenseful story surrounding the psychic Alma, a peculiar and disturbing odyssey that adds depth to her devastating quest for revenge and immediacy to gameplay. Origin began as a secret military project run by the Aramacham Technology Corporation (ATC) . In an experiment run by Alma's own father, her DNA was used to create two clones that possessed her impressive psychic powers in an attempt to engineer a telepathic military commander. In the end, the research team became worried about the dangers of Alma's powers, and they tried to kill her.While her heart stopped beating and her physical body died, her psychic energy continued to exist, and she manifested herself in many forms, including both a child and a deformed adult figure that betrays the gruesomeness of her ordeal. Due to a string of events tied to both her clones, Alma has escaped the disastrous explosion of the last game and the facility where she was held, and the haunting manifestations of her power are at work all around you, adding an unpredictable, nightmarish quality to the world.Strange Events in a Supernatural SettingIn order to get anywhere in the rubble of the city of Auburn, you'll need to survive firefights, stay calm in the face of surprisingly graphic events, and uncover the terrifying and mysterious nature of your real enemies. Your character's phenomenal reflexes allow the much-talked-about slow motion effect from the original title to persist here, giving you an edge in combat and adding to the unique nature of your perspective.Improved Details and Enemy AIAn enhanced graphics engine means more detailed environments to explore and better effects. The vast destruction in the city opens up a huge variety of spaces and enhances the other-worldly feel of your mission, and you better be ready to stay on guard because all-new enemies powered by improved AI don't just act more realistically than their predecessors, they employ advanced combat tactics and know how to use the environment against you. But they aren't the only ones with more resources at their disposal--additional world interaction enhancements allow you to create cover and protect yourself or remove obstacles from your path.While it may be the horrific action and the details that first catch your eye, the tactical demands and the way story elements are slowly unveiled promise to help keep you interested as gameplay wears on. And for those times when you're not in the mood for a prolonged single-player campaign, this title also offers the ability to battle with or against friends in multiplayer mode.

summary: One of the best PS3 games
reviewText: I bought this the day it came out and have had an absolute blast playing it.  The story, weapons, graphics, Move controls, epic boss fights...everything is great.  Even if you've never played the other two Resistance games, you'll have fun with this without feeling lost.  It's definitely the best of the series and one of the best games I've played this gen.  A must have for PS3 owners.

Resistance 3 is an excellent game. It is not as good as the original game in the series but comes darn close. The campaign is exciting and overall a lot of fun. The weapon wheel is back so you can use any weapon that you have collected at any time. There are a few new weapons to aid your fight against the Chimera along with some classic ones like the Marksman and Bullseye. The new weapons are pretty sweet and a lot of fun to use. Also every weapon has two upgrades that you unlock which gives you incentives to diversify the weapons you use. The campaign has a lot of varied locals along with some really cool level structures that keep that WW2 feel from the original. The game really does a nice job of detail in it's environments. From children's drawings on the wall to actual Resident Evil style creepy hallways you are always drawn into the 50's feel of the game. There are also a lot of destroyed buildings to rummage through along with multiple enemy types to battle against. The regenerative health system has been replaced by a health pack system which makes every move that much more cautious and strategic.  I do recommend that you play the game on a harder difficulty though as in the lower difficulties health packs are too plentiful.The graphics are improved over the predecessor though not up to other Playstation franchises like Killzone or Uncharted. The game also looks pretty good in 3D with good depth along with the some popout from time to time. Playstation Move works well enough but it does take some getting used to and I would recommend not using the Sharp Shooter and just use the Move and Navigation controller without it. It gets really tiring holding the gun for a long period of time.The story in this game is pretty good as you follow Joseph Capelli's journey to stop the Chimera. He is driven by love for his wife and child to save the world. It is a compelling journey but it does have an interesting twist at the end that is a bit disappointing. Everything is wrapped up a little too neatly and it does feel like an end to the series.Overall the game is a major improvement over the second game in the series and is my pick so far for Game of The Year(Until Uncharted 3 comes out). It is well worth the price of admission as it is a fun and epic campaign. Also if you so inclined you can play the campaign co op with a friend via splitscreen which is a big plus in my book.

summary: Im having more fun playing GTA chinatown wars on my DS than this game...
reviewText: Of course I bought into the hype for this game and laid down $60 big ones for it... wow what a big mistake! I will cut to the chase here. The game has almost everything to make an outstanding experience and its missing the most important key element to why we all play games in the first place.Graphics: pretty impressive for an open world sand box game, some of the best I've seenControls: easy to get used to once you understand controlling the horse.Sound: sounds like it should: weapons, people, nothing seems out of placeStory: this game has better acting than most movies and the characters are all diverse and entertaining, not bad at all.GAMEPLAY: here is where the game fails miserably. Most of you (like me) will be in awe for the first few hours of gameplay. Roping some horses, shooting some animals, doing some bounty missions and main missions will be entertaining FOR A WHILE. Then I started to realize how repetitive everything gets. Start a mission, ride your horse from point A to point B while talking to someone on the way. Get to point B, take cover behind a rock, shoot some guys (auto aim makes it way to easy to win, i turned it off) then your pretty much done. About 85%  of the missions are like this, and it sucks. Shooting animals gets old after about an hour, roping horses is boring. "Random" events that happen along the trail are repetitive. I found no real reason to stray from the conveniently placed trails all along the landscape because there is really nothing to see off the road. Im sure these things won't bother a lot of people but I can't stand this type of gameplay. Like I said, Chinatown wars is a game that is always keeping me engaged with tasks to do and challenges that are fun to complete. This isn't a review of chinatown wars, but when I have more fun playing a Rockstar game on a 3 inch DS screen than I do playing on a 32 inch hi def flatscreen; something is definitely wrong. Red Dead Redemption would do better as a movie than a game. Rent first or borrow from a friend, you be the judge.

description: You are Solid Snake, a superspy who's half James Bond, half Snake Plissken, and you are mean. Your mission isn't terribly new (infiltrate a terrorist base and blow everything up), but the gameplay is: your numerous enemies are watching for you, and you are encouraged to sneak rather than simply charge in. Every level brings new challenges. You fight snipers, invisible ninjas, psychic warriors, and even an M-1 tank! As the father of the modern spy game genre, this game is an instant classic.Your allies and superiors speak to you via a cool, implanted radio,  monitoring your progress, offering  tips--but failing to give you the full story. The combination of a mysterious and engaging plot and high in-game tension makes this a thrilling ride. Campy humor also abounds as you rescue beautiful women, verbally spar with your allies, and blow up enemies in the bathroom. A user-friendly control interface allows for sniping, hiding, crawling, and running, and the graphics leave nothing to be desired. If you like espionage, spy movies, or just want to own and play a piece of gaming history, then this is a must have.Metal Gear Solidis one of the all-time greats. Game tip: Secretly attach plastic explosives behind an enemy, sneak out of the room, and see what happens.--Allen StewartPros:Story well-integrated into gameplayStealth favored over brute forceChallenging puzzlesCons:Puzzles can be frustratingTorture scene too intense for younger gamers
summary: One of the Playstation's best, period
reviewText: In many ways I always liked playing the original Playstation since the amount of games that were must-plays to the undiscovered gems always seemed plentiful so you never felt like you didn't buy a machine for at most, 5 or 6 games. Metal Gear Solid was quite a fun and intriguing release and it brought a more cinematic telling into the stories and although short and plotwise it can get into philosophy-speak a bit too often (though at least it's easier to swallow than Sons of Liberty), it was still one of the more unique play experiences found on the console.Story: You play as Solid Snake who's sent to Shadow Moses Island in Alaska to rescue DARPA Chief Donald Anderson and ArmsTech President Kenneth Baker as well as stop the terrorist's plans on launching a nuke. But that's just the start of it as we get FOXHOUND members, special elite soldiers who went rogue, a big beast of a machine and Snake's own connection to the leader of the group.Graphics: Since this is the original Playstation, you kind of have to take everything at face value: they look blocky now and lack the clarity of Sons of Liberty or the huge polish of Snake Eater but it was on a lesser console so it makes sense. But at the time it was impressive with lots of cutscenes, done very movie-like and indeed the environments were well handled.Sound/Music: Along with the Lunar series, the MGS series has always been prime examples of how voice acting should be done. Instead of overeager voices or just robotic delivery, it's very easy to get involved with the story when the actors do a great job at balancing the quieter moments with the more plot-based information. The music does a good job as well though it's used rather sparingly.Gameplay: Unlike other games were it's encouraged to go crazy on your enemies, the MGS series rewards stealth and non-killing to progress. Use tranquilizer guns or knock out enemies, the object is to be seen as little as possible. Even then you have a huge assortment of goodies at your disposal that inexplicably can be stored in Snake's tiny pockets. From sniper rifles to 2 different kind of missile launchers, automatics and handguns and goggles, there's plenty to use should you get caught. Aiding your ability to not be seen is the radar where a blue cone represents your enemy's field of vision which you avoid though you can distract them by making noise such as knocking on walls.Cutscenes are well-handled from FMV-types which detail nuclear histories and such while there's others which handle the in-game cinematics like meeting characters. But Snake also talks through the CODEC, a radio and video communication which shows a black screen, text and 2 character portraits and though it's handy to read all the heavy plot scenes, it feels strange for character moments. Get used to that ring too since you'll be hearing it a lot as you play the game. The other negative people might have is its length which doesn't really feel long and it's actually perfectly paced and it doesn't feel like the game got extended just for the sake of adding more stuff to do.Although we have the remake with the Twin Snakes, I felt the original is the best version and while graphically it shows its age, it's still an engrossing playthrough.

I love Street Fighter IV and I was really looking forward to this. What I got in the package was one of the most disappointing games I've ever played.On the surface it looks good - it's done by the same team (Dimps) that made SF4. It has an equal mix of SF and Tekken characters, including a few out of Capcom's comfort zone (like Poison). Superficially, the characters, movesets, blocking, and systems were worked to accomodate both styles. The game is 2-vs.-2 to encourage teamwork. It all sounds great, the characters look great (if you're a fan of the SF4 style, of course), it should've been awesome.Problems are immediately obvious. First of all, it's as bare-bones as you can get. There's arcade mode, tutorial mode, challenge mode, and online. Capcom keeps putting out these bare-bones fighters and it's very frustrating to see a beautiful, feature-packed game like BlazBlue - or Tekken! - in comparison.That said, even a mediocre online mode can make up for shortcomings on the feature list. SFxT isn't even close. The game plays terribly online. Early on, the sound cut out like crazy in every match - Capcom claimed that they could fix the sound but the lag would still be a problem. So now we have a game with okay sound but more lag. Capcom claims the code was custom-written for the purpose of playing 2-vs.-2 online, but I would argue that 1-vs.-1 should still be a priority. In any case, the 360 version's online mode doesn't even support tag team with 2 people on the same machine.The game doesn't play well. Despite the fact that it uses a Tekken Tag like KO system (where you only have to knock out one guy instead of both to win), matches often come right down to the wire. The issue here is that combos are extremely damaging, so the normal response is a lot of keep-away. It's boring - neither tense and exacting like SFIV or fast-paced and technical like Marvel vs. Capcom 3. Capcom also threw in a comeback mechanic (calling it Pandora), but it's pretty terrible and doesn't fit into the game at all - it plays like Capcom added it because every game has a comeback mechanic and they needed to put one in here. They didn't.There's also the gem system, which is just a bizarre and ill-conceived addition. The idea here is that you can slot gems which give you additional powers in the match. They give either passive or active bonuses after meeting certain conditions. The problem is that the gems are arbitrary and poorly balanced. Capcom also took a hard-line on the gems, claiming that the game was balanced with them and could never be disabled. This pretty much doomed the game's long-term viability.Looking at the gems, it's clear that SFxT was Capcom's push to nickel-and-dime their customers. Locked characters, expensive costumes, and gem packs all turned the game into a decidedly chintzy affair. This was just insult being added to injury - not only did Capcom deliver a bad game, but they larded it up with terrible DLC. Well, I doubt they are making much money off the DLC today.I don't even know why I am writing this - Street Fighter X Tekken deservedly flopped. This is Capcom's worst fighter since Capcom Fighting Jam/Evolution, which released in 2004. Both Tekken and Street Fighter fans hated it. Tekken X Street Fighter (Namco's contribution) may never come out, so this might be all we get from that partnership. It was probably never a good idea - Capcom vs. SNK worked because the games are fairly similar on a basic level. Tekken and Street Fighter are very different games. Well, let's just bury this and move on to better titles.

reviewText: Despite what the review title says and will say, I will say right now that if you loved Super Street Fighter IV, you're undoubtedly going to have a good time with Street Fighter x Tekken. The game plays identically to that of the frantic fighting action of its predecessor(s). This time, of course, you're treated to a cast of characters from fellow Namco franchise, Tekken, and they surprisingly fit into the Street Fighter gameplay style pretty well.That's just about the highest I could praise the game, though. While I do adore the unique and colorful atmosphere of the fighting arenas (They even change up round after round!), the soundtrack and voices are notable issues here. I don't think I've ever heard a less memorable soundtrack coming from a Capcom game, and quite a few tunes contain unappealing guitar riffs. If anything, the title screen theme is the best song in the entire game.While I did mention earlier that the game plays like Super Street Fighter IV, it also borrows a well-defining mechanic from the Marvel vs. Capcom series: The tag-team functions. Basically, instead of having to pick out only one character, you can select from two on the character roster as a team. If the character you're playing as is on low health, swap him out quickly with the other guy who, if you haven't already used him, is equipped with a full life bar. The tag-team action can be used in a somewhat strategic manner, but often does it come off as visually frustrating to see that I nearly knock down my opponent, only to see him/her be swapped out by a whole new one to take down.And then there's Capcom's incredibly horrendous business practices that single-handedly butchered the entire experience for many players. What am I referring to exactly? The absence of couch co-op and, worse yet, an overabundance of DISC-LOCKED CONTENT that you have to pay extra for despite the content already being on the disc. Clearly, they were trying to use this game as a cash grab of some sort.If you have an iOS device, I highly recommend you buy the iOS version of Street Fighter x Tekken to satisfy your SFxTK needs. It's what I consider the definitive version of the game, oddly enough. It not only has absolutely NO DLC, but the game also makes it easy to pick up and play, you don't have to pay for Xbox Live or anything like that to play online matches, and best of all, it's only $3! Heck, even the tag-team mechanics have improved drastically to incorporate more strategy (And now one of the two characters does not rely on a health bar, but is only sent out to fight for a short period of time).

description: As Vincent, a man recently succumbed to the irresistible beauty of the game's titular diversion, players find themselves swept into a treacherous love triangle. Catherine's core themes-those of free will, of the delicate nature of relationships and the choices we make within them, marry perfectly with the intense, terror-filled gameplay that serves to accurately reflect Vincent's growing sense of anxiety. It is an experience wholly unlike any to come before it, and is certain to leave gamers talking and thinking about Vincent's tribulations long after the credits have rolled.
reviewText: To be honest, I didn't know what to expect from this game. I had heard very good things about it and I love unique games so I figured I would give it a try. I am glad I did as its really one of the more unique and entertaining games I have played in a long time. Basically the story aspect of the game unfolds while Vincent, the main character, is awake and the puzzle/platforming side of the game occurs when Vincent goes to sleep at night. The story is surprisingly good and doesn't just feel tacked on. The puzzle/platforming side is both entertaining and challenging. It took me like 5 attempts just to get through the 3rd night. With that being said, its not the frustratingly difficult kind of challenge. Each time you replay a section, you should be able to proceed a little farther so I dont think many people will have the problem of getting stuck. You can always lower the difficulty if you do. This game does deal with adult themes so I wouldn't suggest buying this for your children.Overall this is honestly one of the more unique games I have ever come across and the developers do a great job of tying everything together. It has great characters, great dialogue, a great story, and most importantly a very entertaining and challenging puzzle/platforming side of the game that will keep you coming back for more even after you have completed the game. To be perfectly honest, I thought this game was going to be really lame when I first heard about it being developed. Well, I openly admit I was dead wrong.Highly recommended especially if you enjoy unique games.

summary: Better Late than Never - Simply Outstanding!
reviewText: Yes I am a little late to the Mass Effect party but as the title of my review states, its better late than never. I actually purchased this a few months after it was released but never got around to playing it. Its a shame that it took me this long as its easily one of the best games out for the 360. Its not perfect but its pretty close.One of the most impressive aspect to this game is the facial expressions from the characters you speak to. This is honestly one of the first games I can remember where the mouth and lip movements are actually animated properly in regards to what they are saying. Its not just a mouth flapping in the wind. This, along with outstanding facial renderings, really bring the characters in this game to life. The other thing that really sticks out quality wise is the story. This is not some hack story thrown together by a mediocre studio. Bioware is a AAA studio and they certainly dont disappoint with Mass Effect. The story is deep, engaging, and most importantly extremely entertaining to watch unfold. There are multiple paths that players can take and your choices can significantly change certain aspects of the story.The combat system in Mass Effect is outstanding. There are multiple character options in regards to combat but overall they are a balance between one of two systems. The first uses regular weapons like assault rifles, shotguns, and sniper rifles and the 2nd system uses what are called biotics. Biotics are very much like The Force abilities in Star Wars. They include abilities like push, lift, shields etc.. You can choose to focus on either one or a combination of both. This one aspect to the game by itself makes the replay value increase dramatically.As great as this game is, it does have a few flaws. First and foremost the design on many of the outposts is extremely repetitive. In fact, most of the colonies you visit have the same exact buildings. Then there is the whole hunting for materials. While driving around in the rover is extremely fun, it does get a bit tedious looking for those materials. Another big flaw is with the money. The money system is pretty much worthless as its so easy to get that you wind up with a huge wad of cash with absolutely nothing to spend it on. Both times I finished the game I was maxed out with money which is 9,999,999 credits. Basically you have very little money in the beginning of the game and that is when you really could use it the most. By the time you get a good chunk of cash, you no longer need it as items are easily found all over the place and your already well stocked equipment wise by the time you save up any significant quantity of money, hence there really isn't much you can buy as you will most likely already own it by the time you can afford it. The only other thing I can think of that bothered me was the elevators. Technology has advanced by light years in this game. Mankind has achieved faster than light travel and has colonized the galaxy. Elevators on the other hand have appeared to regress technology wise as they are incredibly slow and Bioware makes you ride it out as there is no fast travel option of skipping the ride.While that may sound like a lot of complaints, its really not. Most of this games problems are small and easily ignored. Overall Mass Effect is easily one of the best RPG's of this generation. In case your unaware Mass Effect 2 is already out and a third title is on the way. This was planned from the beginning and not just a response to great sales.Bottom line - Bioware has done it again. Mass Effect is an outstanding game and if you enjoy these types of games and haven't played it yet then it should go at the very top of your to play list. Like I said to start this review, its better late than never. I am moving onto ME 2!5 Stars!
